The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands is amended to clarify temporary absence of officials and authorize short-term borrowing by the government. The laws of the Virgin Islands may define temporary absence of the Governor or Lieutenant Governor, and the legislature may issue notes in anticipation of taxes and revenues, not exceeding the anticipated amount for the year. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands allows for short-term borrowing by the government through issuing notes in anticipation of taxes and revenues, which must mature and be redeemed within 1 year. No extension or additional notes can be issued until all outstanding principal and interest on previous notes have been paid. SEC. 2 of the amendment to P.L. 94-392 establishes a parity lien for bonds issued for payment, removing the previous priority system based on issue date. The amendments apply to obligations issued after the enactment of the Act. The "Virgin Islands Development Act of 1997" establishes the Commission on the Economic Future of the Virgin Islands, consisting of 6 members appointed by the President. 3 members are selected from nominations by the Governor of the Virgin Islands, and the Secretary of the Interior serves as an ex-officio member. The President designates a Chairperson from the appointed members. The Chairperson of the Commission is the chief executive officer and may delegate executive functions to staff. Vacancies are filled as per original appointments. Members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for expenses. The Commission has the power to hold hearings and receive evidence as deemed appropriate. The Commission has the authority to take testimony, receive evidence, use the United States mail, incur expenses, and enter into contracts. The Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. The President can direct federal agencies to assist the Commission by furnishing information upon request. The Commission is required to provide necessary information to the President and Congress regarding policies for the Virgin Islands' economy through 2020. Personnel can be detailed to the Commission on a reimbursable basis without loss of seniority or pay. The Commission is tasked with providing recommendations on the Virgin Islands' economy through 2020, including analyzing private sector development, tourism trends, infrastructure, education, health, and environmental needs. They will also assess the Virgin Islands' capability to meet projected needs based on various forecasts. The Commission is responsible for gathering demographic, economic, revenue, and expenditure data from 1972 to 1997. A report with recommendations must be submitted to the President and relevant committees by June 30, 1999. $300,000 per year is authorized for the Commission's work in fiscal years 1998 and 1999. The Commission will terminate 3 months after submitting the report.
